revision.text:
This is a compilation of initialisms and acronyms commonly used in [[mass spectrometry]].<ref name='Busch2002'>{{cite journal |last=Busch |first=Kenneth L. |date=February 2002 |title=SAMS:Speaking with Acronyms in Mass Spectrometry |journal=Spectroscopy |volume=17 |issue=2 |url=http://spectroscopyonline.findanalytichem.com/spectroscopy/data/articlestandard//spectroscopy/052002/8463/article.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-02-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Busch |first=Kenneth L. |date=May 1, 2006 |title=Acronyms in Mass Spectrometry |work=spectroscopyonline.com |url=http://www.chromatographyonline.com/acronyms-mass-spectrometry |accessdate=September 22, 2015}}</ref>
{{Compact ToC|symnum=yes|seealso=no|refs=yes|notes=no|extlinks=yes}}
==A== * ADI – Ambient desorption ionization * AE – Appearance energy * AFADESI – air flow-assisted desorption electrospray ionization * AFAI – Air flow-assisted ionization<ref name="HeTang2011">{{cite journal|last1=He|first1=Jiuming|last2=Tang|first2=Fei|last3=Luo|first3=Zhigang|last4=Chen|first4=Yi|last5=Xu|first5=Jing|last6=Zhang|first6=Ruiping|last7=Wang|first7=Xiaohao|last8=Abliz|first8=Zeper|title=Air flow assisted ionization for remote sampling of ambient mass spectrometry and its application|journal=Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry|volume=25|issue=7|year=2011|pages=843–850|issn=0951-4198|doi=10.1002/rcm.4920|pmid=21416520}}</ref> * AFAPA – Aerosol flowing atmospheric-pressure afterglow * AGHIS - All-glass heated inlet system<ref name="Peterson1962">{{cite journal|last1=Peterson|first1=Lowell|title=Mass Spectrometer All-Glass Heated Inlet.|journal=Analytical Chemistry|volume=34|issue=13|year=1962|pages=1850–1851|issn=0003-2700|doi=10.1021/ac60193a054}}</ref> * AIRLAB – Ambient infrared laser ablation<ref name="O’BrienWilliams2015">{{cite journal|last1=O’Brien|first1=Jeremy T.|last2=Williams|first2=Evan R.|last3=Holman|first3=Hoi-Ying N.|title=Ambient Infrared Laser Ablation Mass Spectrometry (AIRLAB-MS) of Live Plant Tissue with Plume Capture by Continuous Flow Solvent Probe|journal=Analytical Chemistry|volume=87|issue=5|year=2015|pages=2631–2638|issn=0003-2700|doi=10.1021/ac503383p|pmid=25622206}}</ref> * [[accelerator mass spectrometry|AMS]] – Accelerator mass spectrometry * [[atomic mass unit|AMU]] – Atomic mass unit * AP – Appearance potential * [[MALDI|AP MALDI]] – Atmospheric pressure matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization * [[atmospheric pressure chemical ionization|APCI]] – Atmospheric pressure chemical ionization * [[atmospheric pressure ionization|API]] – Atmospheric pressure ionization * [[atmospheric pressure photoionization|APPI]] – Atmospheric pressure photoionization * ASAP – Atmospheric Sample Analysis Probe * [[American Society for Mass Spectrometry|ASMS]] – American Society for Mass Spectrometry
==B== * BP – Base peak * [[blackbody infrared radiative dissociation|BIRD]] – Blackbody infrared radiative dissociation<ref name='Dunbar_2003'>{{cite journal |last=Dunbar |first=Robert C. |date=2004 |title=BIRD (blackbody infrared radiative dissociation): Evolution, principles, and applications |journal=Mass Spectrometry Reviews |doi=10.1002/mas.10074 |pmid=14732935 |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=127–58|bibcode=2004MSRv...23..127D }}</ref>
==C== * CRF – Charge remote fragmentation * CSR – Charge stripping reaction * [[chemical ionization|CI]] – Chemical ionization * CA – Collisional activation * [[collisionally activated dissociation|CAD]] – Collisionally activated dissociation * [[collision-induced dissociation|CID]] – Collision-induced dissociation * CRM – Consecutive reaction monitoring * [[fast atom bombardment|CF-FAB]] – Continuous flow fast atom bombardment * CRIMS – Chemical Reaction Interface Mass Spectrometry<ref>{{cite journal | title = CRIMS: Chemical reaction interface mass spectrometry | journal = Mass Spectrometry Reviews | doi = 10.1002/mas.1280130403 | year = 1994 | last1 = Abramson | first1 = Fred P. | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 341–356| bibcode = 1994MSRv...13..341A }}</ref> * CTD - Charge Transfer Dissociation<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoffmann WD, Jackson GP | title = Charge transfer dissociation (CTD) mass spectrometry of peptide cations using kiloelectronvolt helium cations | journal = Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry | volume = 25 | issue = 11 | pages = 1939–43 | date = November 2014 | pmid = | doi = 10.1007/s13361-014-0989-6 | bibcode = 2014JASMS.tmp..208H }}</ref>
==D== * [[delayed extraction|DE]] – Delayed extraction * DADI – Direct analysis of daughter ions * [[Desorption atmospheric pressure photoionization|DAPPI]] – Desorption atmospheric pressure photoionization * DEP – Direct exposure probe * [[Desorption electrospray ionization|DESI]] – Desorption electrospray ionization * DIOS – Desorption ionization on silicon<ref name='10.1038/20400'> {{cite journal | title = Desorption–ionization mass spectrometry on porous silicon | journal = Nature | doi = 10.1038/20400 | year = 1999 | last1 = Buriak | first1 = Jillian M. | last2 = Wei | first2 = Jing | last3 = Siuzdak | first3 = Gary | volume = 399 | issue = 6733 | pages = 243–6 | pmid = 10353246| bibcode = 1999Natur.399..243W }}</ref> * DIP – direct insertion probe * [[DART ion source|DART]] – Direct analysis in real time * DLI – Direct liquid introduction
==E== * [[electron affinity|EA]] – Electron affinity * [[electron capture dissociation|ECD]] – Electron-capture dissociation * [[electron capture ionization|ECI]] – Electron capture ionization * [[electron-detachment dissociation|EDD]] – Electron-detachment dissociation * [[electron ionization|EI]] – Electron ionization (or electron impact) * [[European Journal of Mass Spectrometry|EJMS]] – European Journal of Mass Spectrometry * [[electrostatic energy analyzer|ESA]] – Electrostatic energy analyzer * [[electrospray ionisation|ES/ESI]] – Electrospray ionisation * [[electron-transfer dissociation|ETD]] – Electron-transfer dissociation * [[electronvolt|eV]] – Electronvolt
==F== * [[high-field asymmetric waveform ion mobility spectrometry|FAIMS]] – High-field asymmetric waveform ion mobility spectrometry * [[fast atom bombardment|FAB]] – Fast atom bombardment * [[fast atom bombardment|FIB]] – Fast ion bombardment * [[field desorption|FD]] – Field desorption * FFR – Field-free region * [[field ionization|FI]] – Field ionization * [[Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance|FT-ICR MS]] – Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer * [[Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance|FTMS]] – Fourier transform mass spectrometer
==G== * GDMS – Glow discharge mass spectrometry
==H== * [[Hydrogen–deuterium exchange|HDX]] – Hydrogen/deuterium exchange *HCD – Higher-energy C-trap dissociation
==I== * [[Isotope-coded affinity tag|ICAT]] – Isotope-coded affinity tag * [[inductively coupled plasma|ICP]] – Inductively coupled plasma * [[ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer|ICRMS]] – Ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer * [[isotope dilution mass spectrometry|IDMS]] – Isotope dilution mass spectrometry * [[International Journal of Mass Spectrometry|IJMS]] – International Journal of Mass Spectrometry * [[infrared multiphoton dissociation|IRMPD]] – Infrared multiphoton dissociation * [[ion kinetic energy spectrometry|IKES]] – Ion kinetic energy spectrometry * [[ion mobility spectrometry|IMS]] – Ion mobility spectrometry * [[International Mass Spectrometry Conference|IMSC]] – International Mass Spectrometry Conference * [[International Mass Spectrometry Foundation|IMSF]] – International Mass Spectrometry Foundation * [[isotope ratio mass spectrometry|IRMS]] – Isotope ratio mass spectrometry * [[ion trap|IT]] – Ion trap * [[Quadrupole ion trap|ITMS]] – Ion trap mass spectrometry * [[Ion trap mobility spectrometry|ITMS]] – Ion trap mobility spectrometry * [[iTRAQ]] – isobaric tag for relative and absolute quantitation
==J== * [[Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry|JASMS]] – Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry * [[JEOL]] – Japan Electro-Optics Laboratory * [[Journal of Mass Spectrometry|JMS]] – Journal of Mass Spectrometry
==K== * KER – Kinetic energy release * KERD – Kinetic energy release distribution
==L== * [[laser desorption|LD]] – Laser desorption * [[laser desorption ionization|LDI]] – Laser desorption ionization * [[laser ionization|LI]] – Laser ionization * [[laser microprobe mass spectrometry|LMMS]] – Laser microprobe mass spectrometry * [[Linear ion trap|LIT]] – Linear ion trap * [[liquid secondary ionization|LSI]] – Liquid secondary ionization * LSII – Laserspray ionization ''inlet''
==M== * [[mass-analyzed ion kinetic energy spectrometry|MIKES]] – Mass-analyzed ion kinetic energy spectrometry * [[mass spectrometer|MS]] – Mass spectrometer * [[mass spectrometry|MS]] – Mass spectrometry * [[Tandem mass spectrometry|MS/MS]] – Mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry, i.e. tandem mass spectrometry * [[matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization|MALDI]] – Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization * MAII - [[Matrix assisted inlet ionization]] ''Inlet'' * MAIV - Matrix Assisted Ionization ''Vacuum'' * [[membrane introduction mass spectrometry|MIMS]] – Membrane introduction mass spectrometry, membrane inlet mass spectrometry, membrane interface mass spectrometry * [[microchannel plate|MCP]] – Microchannel plate * [[Tandem mass spectrometry|MS<sup>n</sup>]] – Multiple stage mass spectrometry * [[microchannel plate|MCP]] – Microchannel plate * [[multiphoton ionization|MPI]] – Multiphoton ionization * [[Multiple Reaction Monitoring|MRM]] – Multiple reaction monitoring
==N== * [[Nanoelectromechanical systems mass spectrometer|NEMS-MS]] - Nanoelectromechanical systems mass spectrometry * [[Negative electron-transfer dissociation|NETD]] – Negative electron-transfer dissociation * [[chemical ionization|NICI]] – Negative ion chemical ionization * [[neutralization reionization mass spectrometry|NRMS]] – Neutralization reionization mass spectrometry
==O== * oa-TOF – Orthogonal Acceleration Time of Flight * [[Journal of Mass Spectrometry|OMS]] – Organic Mass Spectrometry (Journal)
==P== * [[Plasma desorption mass spectrometry|PDI]] – Plasma desorption/ionization * [[Plasma desorption mass spectrometry|PDMS]] – Plasma desorption mass spectrometry * PAD – Post-acceleration detector * PSD – Post-source decay * [[pyrolysis mass spectrometry|PyMS]] – Pyrolysis mass spectrometry
==Q== * [[quadrupole ion storage trap|QUISTOR]] – Quadrupole ion storage trap * [[quadrupole ion trap|QIT]] – Quadrupole ion trap * [[quadrupole mass spectrometer|QMS]] – Quadrupole mass spectrometer
==R== * [[Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry|RCM]] – Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry * [[Resonance enhanced multiphoton ionization|REMPI]] – Resonance enhanced multiphoton ionization * [[residual gas analyzer|RGA]] – Residual gas analyzer * [[resonance ionization|RI]] – Resonance ionization
==S== * SAII – Solvent Assisted Ionization ''Inlet'' * [[Surface-enhanced laser desorption/ionization|SELDI]] – Surface-enhanced laser desorption/ionization * [[Sensitive high resolution ion microprobe|SHRIMP]] – Sensitive high resolution ion microprobe * [[Selected ion flow tube mass spectrometry|SIFT]] – Selected ion flow tube * [[SILAC]] – Stable isotope labelling by amino acids in cell culture * SIM – Selected ion monitoring * SIR – Selected ion recording * SNMS – Secondary neutral mass spectrometry * SRM – Selected reaction monitoring * [[Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance#Stored waveform inverse Fourier transform|SWIFT]] – Stored waveform inverse Fourier transform * [[surface-induced dissociation|SID]] – Surface-induced dissociation * [[surface-induced reaction|SIR]] – Surface-induced reaction * [[surface ionization|SI]] – Surface ionization * [[Collision-induced dissociation#CID in an FTMS ICR cell .28SORI-CID.29|SORI]] – Sustained off-resonance irradiation
==T== * [[Thermal ionization|TI]] – Thermal ionization * TIC – Total ion current * [[Mass chromatogram#Total ion current (TIC) chromatogram|TICC]] – Total ion current chromatogram * TLF – Time-lag focusing * [[Tandem mass tags|TMT]] – Tandem mass tags * [[time-of-flight mass spectrometer|TOF-MS]] – Time-of-flight mass spectrometer
==V== * VG – Vacuum Generators (company)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://web.mit.edu/speclab/www/Facility/MS/ms_acro.html Mass Spectroscopy Acronym Page at MIT] {{Mass spectrometry}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} The '''''Oxford Classical Dictionary''''' ('''''OCD''''') is generally considered "the best one-volume dictionary on antiquity,"<ref>Markus Sehlmeyer, review of ''Oxford Classical Dictionary'', ed. Simon Hornblower and Antony Spawforth, ''Bryn Mawr Classical Review'' 97.9.06 (1997). [http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/1997/97.9.06.html]</ref><ref>See also, Gregory S. Bucher, review of ''Oxford Classical Dictionary'', ed. Simon Hornblower and Antony Spawforth, ''Bryn Mawr Classical Review'' 2003.11.15 (2003). [http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2003/2003-11-15.html]</ref> an encyclopedic work in English consisting of articles relating to [[classical antiquity]] and its civilizations. It was first published in 1949 (''OCD''<sup>1</sup> or ''OCD''), edited by [[Max Cary]] with the assistance of [[H. J. Rose]], H. P. Harvey, and [[Alexander Souter]]. A second edition followed in 1970 (''OCD''<sup>2</sup>), edited by [[Nicholas G. L. Hammond]] and [[H. H. Scullard]], and a third edition in 1996 (''OCD''<sup>3</sup>), edited by [[Simon Hornblower]] and [[Antony Spawforth]]. A revised third edition was released in 2003, which is nearly identical to the previous third edition. A fourth edition was published in 2012 (''OCD''<sup>4</sup>), edited by Simon Hornblower, Antony Spawforth, and [[Esther Eidinow]]. In 2016, a fully [http://classics.oxfordre.com/ digital edition] (''OCD''<sup>5</sup>) launched online, edited by Sander Goldberg (2013–2017) and [[Tim Whitmarsh]] (2018–present). Continuously updated on a monthly basis, this edition incorporates all 6,300 entries from ''OCD''<sup>4</sup> (which are being updated on a rolling basis) as well as newly commissioned entries, and features multimedia content and freely accessible [http://classics.oxfordre.com/page/maps/ maps] of the ancient world.<ref>For all news and information regarding this version of the ''OCD'', see its [http://classics.oxfordre.com/ current official website].</ref><ref>See, also, the [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/oxford-classical-dictionary-9780199381135?lang=en&cc=us catalogue entry] at Oxford University Press for this new online version of the ''OCD''.</ref>
The ''OCD'''s over 6,400 non-blind articles<ref>This information is garnered from the ''OCD''<sup>5</sup> [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/oxford-classical-dictionary-9780199381135?cc=us&lang=en&# catalogue entry] on the Oxford University Press website.</ref> cover everything from the daily life of the ancient Greeks and Romans to their [[geography]], [[religion]], and their historical figures.
==Digital and on-line availability== The fourth edition and the third revised edition of the ''OCD'' are available online for members of subscribed institutions and for subscribed individuals via [http://www.oxford-classicaldictionary3.com/LOGIN?sessionid=7730d99d97a1312d43cbca6e1e4bea6f&authstatuscode=414 Oxford Reference]. The third edition (1996) was also available on [[CD-ROM]], but it is partially incompatible with more recent versions of [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and has not been revised or re-released.<ref>Online catalogue entry for the ''OCD'', CD-ROM version, available through the website of Oxford University Press, UK version.[http://global.oup.com/uk/academic/cdromsupport/ocd/]</ref>
The new digital edition is accessible online to institutional and individual subscribers via the ''[http://classics.oxfordre.com/ Oxford Research Encyclopedias]''. Entry extracts/summaries and select full-length entries are freely available to non-subscribing individuals.
==''Oxford Companion to Classical Civilization''== The ''Oxford Companion to Classical Civilization'' (''OCCC''), part of the [https://global.oup.com/academic/content/series/o/oxford-companions-oc/?cc=us&lang=en Oxford Companions] series of Oxford University Press, is an independent publication consisting of a selection of articles from the ''OCD'', with accompanying illustrations. The first edition was published in 1998 (''OCCC''<sup>1</sup> or ''OCCC''), edited by [[Simon Hornblower]] and [[Antony Spawforth]], and contains over 600 articles selected from the ''OCD''<sup>3</sup>. A paperback edition was issued in 2004. The current second edition was published in 2014 (''OCCC''<sup>2</sup>), edited by Simon Hornblower, Antony Spawforth, and [[Esther Eidinow]], and contains over 700 articles selected from the ''OCD''<sup>4</sup>.<ref>Information regarding the editions of the ''OCCC'' has been garnered from their [[front matter]] and [[dust jacket]]s.</ref>
==Varia== '''National Latin Exam'''
A copy of the ''OCD'' has traditionally been offered by the [[National Latin Exam]] as a prize for students who obtain four consecutive ascending gold medals on the exam.<ref>"National Latin Exam Awards," from the website of the National Latin Exam. [http://www.nle.org/awards.html#awards_medals]</ref>
==Editions and versions== '''''Oxford Classical Dictionary''''' * ''Oxford Classical Dictionary''. Edited by Max Cary, with the assistance of [[H. J. Rose]], H. P. Harvey, and [[A. Souter]]. Oxford: [[Oxford University Press#The Clarendon Press|Clarendon Press]], 1949. * ''Oxford Classical Dictionary''. Edited by [[Nicholas G. L. Hammond]] and [[H. H. Scullard]]. 2nd ed. Oxford: [[Oxford University Press#The Clarendon Press|Clarendon Press]], 1970. * ''Oxford Classical Dictionary''. Edited by [[Simon Hornblower]] and Antony Spawforth. 3rd ed. Oxford and New York: [[Oxford University Press]], 1996. {{ISBN|978-0-19-866172-6}}. * ''Oxford Classical Dictionary''. Edited by Simon Hornblower and Antony Spawforth. 3rd rev. ed. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2003. {{ISBN|978-0-19-860641-3}}. * ''Oxford Classical Dictionary''. Edited by Simon Hornblower, Antony Spawforth, and [[Esther Eidinow]]. 4th ed. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-19-954556-8}}. *''[http://classics.oxfordre.com/ Oxford Classical Dictionary]''. Edited by [[Tim Whitmarsh]]. Digital ed. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-938113-5}}.
'''''Oxford Companion to Classical Civilization''''' * ''Oxford Companion to Classical Civilization''. Edited by Simon Hornblower and Antony Spawforth. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 1998, 2004. {{ISBN|978-0-19-860165-4}} (hb), {{ISBN|978-0-19-860958-2}} (pb). * ''Oxford Companion to Classical Civilization''. Edited by Simon Hornblower, Antony Spawforth, and Esther Eidinow. 2nd ed. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2014. {{ISBN|978-0-19-870677-9}}.
==See also== * [[Pauly–Wissowa|''Realencyclopädie der classischen Altertumswissenschaft'']], the comprehensive multivolume classical encyclopedia, also known as Pauly-Wissowa and ''RE'', published in German and English, and explained more fully on [[:de:Pauly-Wissowa|Wikipedia's German site]] * [[Pauly-Wissowa#Der Kleine Pauly, Der Neue Pauly and Brill's New Pauly|''Der Kleine Pauly'' (''KlP''), ''Der Neue Pauly'' (''DNP''), and ''Brill's New Pauly'' (''BNP'')]], subsequent versions of the ''RE'', and generally explained more fully on [[:de:Pauly-Wissowa|Wikipedia's German site]] * [[Dictionnaire des Antiquités Grecques et Romaines|''Dictionnaire des antiquités grecques et romaines'']] (''DAGR''), an extensive multivolume classical encyclopedia published in French * [[:de:Reallexikon für Antike und Christentum|''Reallexikon für Antike und Christentum'']] (''RAC''), a comprehensive and still-in-production encyclopedia on [[late antiquity]] and the interactions between ancient Christians, Jews, Greeks, and Romans, published in German * [[Harper's Dictionary of Classical Antiquities|''Harper's Dictionary of Classical Literature and Antiquities'']]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-oxford-classical-dictionary-9780199545568?q=Oxford%20classical%20dictionary&lang=en&cc=us Oxford University Press USA, catalogue entry for the ''OCD''<sup>4</sup>] * [http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780199545568.do?keyword=oxford+classical+dictionary&sortby=bestMatches Oxford University Press UK, catalogue entry for the ''OCD''<sup>4</sup>] * [https://www.amazon.com/Oxford-Classical-Dictionary-Simon-Hornblower/dp/0199545561/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1423409544&sr=1-1&keywords=oxford+classical+dictionary Amazon.com's catalogue entry for the ''OCD''<sup>4</sup>] * [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Oxford-Classical-Dictionary-Esther-Eidinow/dp/0199545561/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1322095096&sr=1-3 Amazon.co.uk's catalogue entry for the ''OCD''<sup>4</sup>] * [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-oxford-companion-to-classical-civilization-9780198706779?lang=en&cc=us Oxford University Press USA, catalogue entry for the ''OCCC''<sup>2</sup>] * [https://www.amazon.com/Oxford-Companion-Classical-Civilization/dp/0198706774/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1423553370&sr=8-1&keywords=oxford+companion+to+classical+civilization Amazon.com's catalogue entry for the ''OCCC''<sup>2</sup>] {{Authority control}} [[Category:1949 books]] [[Category:Encyclopedias of history]] [[Category:Oxford dictionaries]] [[Category:References on Greek mythology]]

revision.comment: Removed unsubstantiated claim - the De Havilland Mosquito didn't 'drone' any more than other aircraft fitted with Rolls Royce Merlin engines.
revision.text:
'''Pippo''' was a mythical plane, unique to [[Northern Italy]], that flew during [[World War II]]. An example of [[oral history]], Pippo is not well documented even in Italy.
Pippo had a distinctive buzz, was rarely if ever seen and flew mainly at night. If people were faithful to the [[Republican Fascist Party|Fascists]], they considered it an [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] plane. If people were supporters of the Allies, it was thought to be a Luftwaffe or Italian Air Force aircraft. No matter what their political allegiances, people personified it as a “he” – the plane and the pilot as one. It is suspected that the Italian government used Pippo as a [[propaganda]] tool to turn ordinary civilians against the Allies, though there is no doubt the plane was real.
It is unclear how Pippo got its name. It may have been a play on the Italian moniker for Disney’s [[Goofy]] character or alternatively was based on the pip-pip sounds it apparently made.
Despite the unthreatening name, people mainly interpreted Pippo as something fearful. Superstition held that one had to block the lights in one’s house or Pippo might fire upon it. It was said to drop exploding pens, poisoned candy, or so-called [[butterfly bomb]]s and to fire on farm workers in fields.
Only decades later did historians surmise the likely origin of the plane. When the Allies gained a foothold in Italy in the later years of the war, pilots began flying tactical night missions to survey and intervene in German troop movements. It never occurred to them that they were inadvertently terrorizing the countryside. In particular, the [[Royal Air Force]] used a plane called the [[de Havilland Mosquito]].
== References in literature == * ''Brideshead Revisited'' – [[Evelyn Waugh]] * ''[http://www.umbertoeco.com/en/the-mysterious-flame-of-queen-loana-2005.html The Mysterious Flame of Queen Loana]'' – [[Umberto Eco]] * ''[http://www.thesidewalkartist.com/ Ciao Bella]'' – Gina Buonaguro & Janice Kirk

revision.text:
[[File:Stroop Report - Cover Page.jpg|thumb|The cover page of the ''"American copy"'' of The Stroop Report with [[International Military Tribunal in Nuremberg]] markings.]] [[File:Stroop Report - Cover Page (Polish Copy).jpg|thumb|The second copy of The Stroop Report from [[Institute of National Remembrance]] in [[Poland]].]] '''The Stroop Report''' is an official report prepared by General [[Jürgen Stroop]] for the [[SS]] chief [[Heinrich Himmler]], recounting the German suppression of the [[Warsaw Ghetto Uprising]] and the liquidation of the ghetto in the spring of 1943. Originally titled '''''The Jewish Quarter of Warsaw is No More!''''' ([[German language|ger.]] ''Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!''), it is commonly referred to as "The Stroop Report". It was published in the 1960s. ==History== The Report was commissioned by [[Friedrich-Wilhelm Krüger]], chief of the SS and police in [[Kraków]] and was intended as a souvenir album for Heinrich Himmler. It was prepared in three distinct leather-bound copies for Himmler, [[Friedrich Krueger]] and Jürgen Stroop, with one unbound "file" copy of the report (''das Konzept'') remaining in Warsaw, in the care of Chief of Staff Max Jesuiter.{{cite book | author=Richard Raskin | title=A Child at Gunpoint: A Case Study in the Life of a Photo | year=2004 | editor = | pages = | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher=Aarhus University Press | location = | isbn=978-8779340992 }} According to a statement given in 1945 by Stroop's adjutant Karl Kaleshke to US authorities in Wiesbaden, he ordered Stroop's copy of the report burnt with other secret documents in Burg Kranzberg.{{cite web |title=Zdjęcia z powstania w getcie |url=http://fototekst.pl/zdjecia-z-powstania-w-getcie/ | author =Tomasz Stempowski |format= |website= |publisher=fototekst.pl |date=March 17, 2013 |lay-format= |accessdate=October 8, 2013 |postscript= }} After the war only two of the four copies were discovered, those belonging to Himmler and Jesuiter.{{cite book | author =[[Jürgen Stroop]] | title =Żydowska dzielnica mieszkaniowa w Warszawie już nie istnieje! / Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!| year =2009 | editor =Andrzej Żbikowski | pages =10–18 | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher = [[:pl:Instytut Pamięci Narodowej|Instytut Pamięci Narodowej]], Żydowski Instytut Historyczny| location =Warsaw | isbn = 978-83-7629-455-1 | url =http://pamiec.pl/ftp/ilustracje/Raport_STROOPA.pdf | format = | accessdate = }} Himmler's copy went to Seventh Army Intelligence Center (SAIC) and Jesuiter's to Military Intelligence Research Section (MIRS) in London. Several sources stated that the German [[German Federal Archives|Bundesarchiv]] also had a copy in [[Koblenz]].[http://collections1.yadvashem.org/notebook_ext.asp?item=47893 Yad Vashem Photo Archive][http://resources.ushmm.org/inquery/uia_doc.php/photos/6443 United States Holocaust Memorial Museum] However, in reply to inquiries by Richard Raskin, the Bundesarchiv stated that the third copy of report was never in their possession. Both copies were introduced as evidence at the [[International Military Tribunal in Nuremberg]], sharing the document number 1061-PS, and used in the trial as "US Exhibit 275". It was first displayed by the chief U.S. prosecutor [[Robert H. Jackson]] for the judges during his opening address.[http://www.holocaust-history.org/works/imt/02/htm/t126.htm International Military Tribunal "Blue Series," Vol. 2, p. 126] The assistant prosecutor dealing with the persecution of the Jews referred to it as "the finest example of ornate German craftsmanship, leather bound, profusely illustrated, typed on heavy bond paper ... the almost unbelievable recital of the proud accomplishment by Major General of Police Stroop".Conot, Justice at Nuremberg, 1983, pp. 269-70. Both copies were also used in Nuremberg in the 1947 trial of [[Oswald Pohl]] as exhibit 503. On June 10, 1948, the Himmler/SAIC copy of the Stroop report and [[Katzmann Report]] were handed over by Fred Niebergal, head of Office of Chief of Counsel for War Crimes – OCCWC, to Bernard Acht, head of the Polish Military Mission in Nuremberg. It was used in Stroop's trial at Warsaw Criminal District Court in July 1951, and transferred afterwards to the KC [[Polish United Workers' Party|PZPR]] archive. In 1952 it was transferred to the ''Główna Komisja Badania Zbrodni Hitlerowskich w Polsce'' (Main Commission for the Investigation of Nazi Crimes in Poland) archive and subsequently to its successor the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] (Polish: ''Instytut Pamięci Narodowej'' or IPN) where it remains. In 1948 the Jesuiter/MIRS copy of the report went to the [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]] (NARA) in [[Washington, D.C.]], where it remains. In 2017, the Stroop Report was submitted by Poland and included in UNESCO's [[Memory of the World]] Register.{{cite web|title=Jürgen Stroop’s Report|website=Memory of the World|publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/memory-of-the-world/register/full-list-of-registered-heritage/registered-heritage-page-4/juergen-stroops-report/|access-date=2018-10-09}} ==Content== [[File:Stanisław Piotrowski - Sprawozdanie Juergena Stroopa.jpg|thumb|First book edition of the Stroop Report from 1948 by [[Stanisław Piotrowski]]]] The Report was a 125-page typed document, bound in black pebble [[leather]], with 53 photographs. It consisted of the following sections: *Summary, with **title page **list of soldiers killed and wounded **the list of combat units involved, and **introduction, signed by Jürgen Stroop in case of IPN copy *Collection of 31 daily reports (German: ''Tägliche Meldungen''), sent from Stroop's Chief of Staff Max Jesuiter to SS Police Leader East Friedrich-Wilhelm Krüger. The reports cover the period of 20 April to 16 May 1943, plus a report from 24 May 1943, and were all signed by Jesuiter. *Series of 53 photographs accompanied by hand-written captions in German [[Sütterlin]] script *The NARA report also has a fourth section with statistics about human losses, types of recovered weapons and amounts of money and valuables taken from Jews. There are slight discrepancies in textual and graphical layout, and in the photographs they contain. ==Text== {{Main|Polish resistance movement in World War II}} The Stroop Report alludes repeatedly to the participation of the Polish Resistance in the Warsaw ghetto uprising. Stroop referred to Polish underground fighters as Polnische Banditen - "Polish Bandits", and noted: {{quote|When we invaded the Ghetto for the first time, the Jews and the Polish bandits succeeded in repelling the participating units, including tanks and armored cars, by a well-prepared concentration of fire. ... The main Jewish battle group, mixed with Polish bandits, had already retired during the first and second day to the so-called Muranowski Square. There, it was reinforced by a considerable number of Polish bandits. Its plan was to hold the Ghetto by every means in order to prevent us from invading it. ... Time and again Polish bandits found refuge in the Ghetto and remained there undisturbed, since we had no forces at our disposal to comb out this maze. ... One such battle group succeeded in mounting a truck by ascending from a sewer in the so-called Prosta [Street], and in escaping with it (about 30 to 35 bandits). ... The bandits and Jews – there were Polish bandits among these gangs armed with carbines, small arms, and in one case a light machine gun – mounted the truck and drove away in an unknown direction.|Jürgen Stroop, 1943From the [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/nowarsaw.html Stroop Report] by SS [[Gruppenführer]] Jürgen Stroop, May 1943.}} {{clear}}
File:Strp012 Jurgen Stroop report p5.jpg|Page 5 of Stroop Report describing German fight against ''Juden mit Polnischen Banditen'' - "Jews with Polish bandits"Jürgen Stroop, "Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!", Warschau 1943, p.5. File:Strp039 Stroop report 27 4 1943.jpg|Page describing military actions on 27 April 1943Jürgen Stroop, "Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!", Warschau 1943. File:Strp040 Stroop report 27 4 1943.jpg|Continuation 27 April 1943 describing fight against a ''jüdisch-polnische Wehrformation'' - "Jewish-Polish combat formation"
== Photographs from the Stroop Report == The IPN copy of the report has 53 photographs on 49 pages, while the NARA copy has the same number of photographs on 52 pages. 37 photographs appear in both copies, although not always with the same size, crop or order and occasionally with different captions. Sixteen shots in each copy are different, although often very similar as they depict the same events. Altogether, in both versions of the report there are 69 unique photographs. The identity of the photographers who accompanied Stroop's headquarters during the operation is unknown. [[Franz Konrad (SS officer)|Franz Konrad]] confessed to taking some of the photographs; the rest were probably taken by photographers from ''Propaganda Kompanie nr 689''. In addition to the photographs found in the reports there were about 45 additional photographs that were not included which according to [[Yad Vashem]] were found in Stroop's possession when he was captured by the Americans after the war.{{cite web|title=The Stroop Collection|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/warsaw_ghetto/collection.asp|website=[[Yad Vashem]]|accessdate=11 April 2016}} Some of those photographs were closely related to those used in the report as they depicted the same events. Many of those additional photographs are described in reputable sources as coming from the Stroop Report, even if they do not appear in either of the surviving copies. The high-quality photographs taken for Stroop constitute a unique documentation of the final stage of liquidation of the Warsaw ghetto. The photographer was permitted access to Stroop's inner circle, to accompany the forces that participated in liquidating the ghetto, and to get close to the combat areas. Apart from a dozen candid photographs taken by Polish firefighter [[Leszek Grzywaczewski]], those are the only photographs of the Ghetto Uprising taken inside the ghetto. Some of them became highly recognized images of World War II and the [[The Holocaust|Shoah]]. Photographic captions in the Report are often highly racist and contain few facts about their content, but are a good reflection of the mindset of the report's authors. They are written in the German Sütterlin script, and in some cases do not match the images. Many of the places, people and events depicted were identified in the years after the report's publication. ===Gallery=== Photographs included in one of the two copies of the Stroop Report. Image captions include a reference and translation of the original German caption (in red) followed by current photo caption. Click on images for more information. Possibly taken 8 May 1943 near Mila 18?[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Lokalizacja_fotografii_kolekcji_Stroopa Stroop Photographs Polish Wiki] File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 06.jpg File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 07.jpg File:Stroop Collection - Jürgen Stroop and other officers - 03.jpg|Jürgen Stroop. Click on photograph for possible ids of other SS officers File:Stroop Collection - Jürgen Stroop and other officers - 07.jpg|Jurgen Stroop File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 01.jpg File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 02.jpg File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 05.jpg|According to USHMM this picture was taken 9 May 1943-20th day of the uprising File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 04.jpg|Taken same place as preceding photograph File:Stroop Collection - Warsaw Ghetto Uprising - Bunker - 03.jpg|Jews taken out of a basement by Germans ==See also== * [[Dachau Trials]] * [[Nuremberg Trials]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links == {{Commons category|Stroop Report}} * {{cite book | author =[[Juergen Stroop]] | others =Sybil Milton, transl. | title =The Stroop Report: "The Jewish Quarter of Warsaw is No More!" | year =1979 | editor = | pages = | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher = Pantheon | location =New York| id = | url = | format = | accessdate = }} (English translation) * {{cite book | author =[[w:Jürgen Stroop|Jürgen Stroop]] | title =Żydowska dzielnica mieszkaniowa w Warszawie już nie istnieje! / Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!| year =2009 | editor =Andrzej Żbikowski | pages = | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher = [[:pl:Instytut Pamięci Narodowej|Instytut Pamięci Narodowej]], Żydowski Instytut Historyczny| location =Warsaw | isbn = 978-83-7629-455-1 | url =http://pamiec.pl/ftp/ilustracje/Raport_STROOPA.pdf | format = | accessdate =April 11, 2016 }} (IPN copy; Polish translation: pages 23–112 and German original: pages 113-238; [[c:Stroop Report photographs - Warsaw copy.pdf|photographs]]) *{{cite web|author=[[w:Jürgen Stroop|Jürgen Stroop]]|title=The Jewish residential quarter in Warsaw has ceased to exist|url=http://www.holocaust-history.org/works/stroop-report/htm/strp001.htm.en|website=www.holocaust-history.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308001834/http://www.holocaust-history.org/works/stroop-report/htm/strp001.htm.en|archive-date=March 8, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} (IPN copy; German original and English translation) *{{cite web| author =[[w:Jürgen Stroop|Jürgen Stroop]]|title=Es gibt keinen jüdischen Wohnbezirk in Warschau mehr!|url=https://research.archives.gov/description/6003996|website=National Archives website|date=May 1943}} (NARA copy; German original: [https://catalog.archives.gov/OpaAPI/media/6003996/content/arcmedia/rediscovery/06314_2011.pdf text], [[c:Stroop Report photographs - NARA copy.pdf|photographs]]) {{Holocaust Poland}} [[Category:Government reports]] [[Category:Holocaust historical documents]] [[Category:Operation Reinhard]] [[Category:Warsaw Ghetto Uprising]] [[Category:1943 documents]] [[Category:World War II photographs]] [[Category:1943 works]] [[Category:1943 in art]] [[Category:1940s photographs]] [[Category:Stroop Report]]

revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Clements Checklist of the Birds of the World | title_orig = | translator = | image = clements checklist cover.gif | caption = The cover of the sixth edition | author = [[James F. Clements]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States|U.S.]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = [[ornithology]] | publisher = [[Cornell University Press]] | release_date = 2007 | media_type = Print ([[hardback]]) | pages = | isbn = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Clements Checklist of Birds of the World''''' is a book by [[Jim Clements]] which presents a list of the bird species of the world.
The most recent printed version is the sixth edition (2007), which was published by [[Cornell University Press]]. Previous editions were published by the author's own imprint, Ibis Publishing. The [[Cornell Lab of Ornithology]] has provided annual updates since then, usually in August, and the most recent version is available online in several formats.<ref>http://www.birds.cornell.edu/clementschecklist/download/</ref> These updates reflect the ongoing changes to bird taxonomy based on published research.
''Clements'' is the official list used by the [[American Birding Association]] for birds globally. [[eBird]] also uses the ''Clements'' checklist as the base list for its [http://ebird.org/content/ebird/about/ebird-taxonomy eBird taxonomy], which in addition to species includes hybrids and other non-species entities reported by birders.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/cup_detail.taf?ti_id=4566 Further information at Cornell University Press website] * [http://www.birds.cornell.edu/clementschecklist Cornell Lab of Ornithology]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clements Checklist of Birds of the World}} [[Category:Ornithological checklists]]
{{ref-book-stub}} {{bird-book-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{infobox television | show_name = The French Chef | image = | caption = | runtime = 28 minutes 46 seconds | country = United States | network = [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]] (producer)
[[National Educational Television|NET]] (1963-1970)
[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] (1970-1973) | first_aired = February 2, 1963 | last_aired = January 14, 1973
'''[[Gusto TV]]'''
(December 2013–present)
'''[[Create (TV network)]]'''
(?–present) | starring = [[Julia Child]] | num_episodes = }} '''''The French Chef''''' is a television [[cooking show]] created and hosted by [[Julia Child]],{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/post/161490-bless-this-mess-sweeping-the-kitchen-with-julia-child/|title=Bless This Mess: Sweeping the Kitchen with Julia Child|work=[[PopMatters]]|date=August 13, 2012|author=J.C. Maçek III}} produced and broadcast by [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]], the [[Public television|public television station]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], from February 2, 1963 to January 14, 1973. It was one of the first [[cooking show]]s on American television. The show grew out of a special presentation Child gave on WGBH based on the book ''[[Mastering the Art of French Cooking]]'' which she co-authored. ''The French Chef'' was produced from 1963 to 1973 by WGBH for [[National Educational Television]] (and later for [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]). Reruns continued on PBS until 1989, and were airing on [[Cooking Channel]] as of 2010. As of September 2016, episodes were being rerun on the new Canadian cooking channel Gusto. As recent as March, 2017, reruns of the show were also seen on the [[American Public Television]] [[Create (TV network)|Create]] channel. ==Format== ''The French Chef'' introduced [[French cuisine|French cooking]] to the United States at a time when it was considered expensive restaurant fare, not suitable for home cooking.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} Child emphasized fresh and, at the time, unusual ingredients. All of the recipes used on ''The French Chef'' had originally appeared in ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking,'' but for the show, Child chose mostly the more domestic recipes from the book,{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} although such showpieces as [[Beef Wellington]], various sorts of [[soufflé]], and some ambitious [[Pastry|pastries]] also made it into the mix if they seemed within the reach of a home cook without staff. The show was done live-to-videotape from start to finish, leaving little room for mistakes. The resulting occasional accidents became a popular trademark of Child's on air presence, used as "[[teachable moment]]s" to encourage viewers to relax about the task's demands. Certain elements became ''[[Motif (narrative)|motif]]s'': Julia's fondness for wine; her distinctive voice; her staunch defense of the use of butter (with [[margarine]] invariably referred to as "that other spread") and [[cream]]; her standard issue "impeccably clean towel"; and her closing line at the end of every show: "''This is Julia Child, [[wikt:bon appétit|Bon appétit]]!''" ==History== {{Expand section|date=April 2011}} {{rquote|right|So good is she that men who have not the slightest intention of going to the kitchen for anything but ice cubes watch her for pure enjoyment.|''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine cover story from November 1966}} When the show began, the budget was so low that "volunteers had to be recruited to wash dishes, and the food sometimes had to be auctioned to the audience afterwards to cover expenses." [[List of Peabody Award winners (1960–1969)#1964|In 1964 Child received a Peabody Award]], crediting her for doing "more than show us how good cooking is achieved; by her delightful demonstrations she has brought the pleasures of good living into many American homes."{{cite web| title=Personal Award for ''The French Chef'' | url= http://www.peabody.uga.edu/winners/details.php?id=865 | publisher= [[Henry W. Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication|Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication]] |work= [[Peabody Award]] | accessdate = 2011-04-28}} In May 1966, her show won a [[18th Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]] for Achievements in Educational Television – Individuals.{{cite web| title=Personal Award for ''The French Chef'' | url= http://www.emmys.com/award_history_search?person=%22Julia+Child%22&start_year=1965&end_year=1995&network=All&web_category=All&winner=All| publisher= [[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |work= [[Primetime Emmy Award]] | accessdate = 2011-04-28}} The August 27, 1968 episode of ''The French Chef'' (rerun from an episode sometime in 1965) ended with the unexpected collapse of an Apple [[Charlotte (cake)|Charlotte]]. The October 31, 1971 episode of ''The French Chef'' (on its ninth anniversary) was the first U.S. television show to be captioned for deaf viewers.{{cite web |title=A Brief History of Captioned Television |url=http://www.ncicap.org/caphist.asp |publisher=[[National Captioning Institute]] |accessdate=2011-04-28 |quote=While the closed captioning service was being developed, there were some programs with "open" captions airing on PBS. In 1972, The French Chef became the very first television program that was accessible to deaf and hard of hearing viewers. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719060406/http://www.ncicap.org/caphist.asp |archivedate=July 19, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The show was produced by Ruth Lockwood and directed by Russell Morash, Russell Fortier, David Griffiths and David B. Atwood.http://www.worldcat.org/title/french-chef-with-julia-child/oclc/59134316?page=citation Film composer John Morris wrote the 2nd theme song of The French Chef. ==Legacy== As part of its growing Twitch Creative content, [[Twitch.tv]] streamed every episode of ''The French Chef'' over a four-day period starting on March 15, 2016, to launch its new food channel.{{cite web |url=https://blog.twitch.tv/julia-child-marathon-introducing-twitch-tv-food-with-a-marathon-of-the-french-chef-77939adf3919 |title=Julia Child Marathon: Introducing the Official Food Channel with The French Chef! |accessdate=2016-03-23}}{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/the-multiverse/2016/03/julia-child-is-the-next-pbs-star-to-get-a-twitch-marathon/ |title=Julia Child is the next PBS star to get a Twitch marathon |accessdate=2016-03-23}} Twitch reported that almost a million viewers watched the marathon.{{cite web |url=https://blog.twitch.tv/food-channel-continues-with-24-7-cooking-programming-20128392bd4f |title=Food Channel Continues with 24/7 Cooking Programming |accessdate=2016-03-23}} ==List of episodes== {| class="wikitable" |- ! || January 14, 1973 |} ==Companion books== Two companion cookbooks were written along with the show. ''The French Chef Cookbook'' was a show-by-show breakdown of the black and white series,{{cite book| author = [[Julia Child]] |title= The French Chef Cookbook | publisher= [[Alfred A. Knopf]]| pages=424 | year= 1963}} while ''From Julia Child's Kitchen'' was a somewhat more ambitious work that was based on the color series but also added considerable extra material.{{cite book| author = [[Julia Child]] |title= From Julia Child's Kitchen | publisher= [[Alfred A. Knopf]]| pages=687 | year= 1970}} ==DVD releases== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} *''Julia Child's Kitchen Wisdom'' (2000) *''Julia and Jacques: Cooking at Home'' (2003) *''Julia Child: America's Favorite Chef'' (2004) *''The French Chef:'' Volume One (2005) *''The French Chef:'' Volume Two (2005) *''The French Chef with Julia Child (As Seen on Public Television). WGBH 2005 [http://www.shoppbs.org/product/index.jsp?productId=2048975&cp=&sr=1&kw=french+chef&origkw=French+Chef&parentPage=search&searchId=3953968]'' 3 DVDs, runtime 432 min. (2005) *''Julia Child! The French Chef'' (2006) *''The French Chef: Julia Child's French Classics'' (2012){{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/French-Chef-Julia-Childs-French-Classics/17372|title=The French Chef – Press Release: 'Julia Child's French Classics' DVD, On Her 100th Birthday|last=Lambert|first=David|date=August 15, 2012|work=[[TVShowsOnDVD.com]]|accessdate=August 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817005111/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/French-Chef-Julia-Childs-French-Classics/17372|archivedate=August 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}} ==References== {{reflist|2|refs= {{cite web| url= http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,843114,00.html | title= Food: Everyone's in the Kitchen | date= November 25, 1966 | publisher= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate= 2011-04-28}} }} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0163936}} *[http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19661125,00.html Cover: Julia Child – Nov. 25, 1966] from ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine *{{emmytvlegends title|french-chef-the}} {{Julia Child}} {{DEFAULTSORT:French Chef}} [[Category:American cooking television series]] [[Category:Television series by WGBH]] [[Category:PBS network shows]] [[Category:1963 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1973 American television series endings]] [[Category:1960s American television series]] [[Category:1970s American television series]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Peabody Award-winning television programs]] [[Category:Alfred A. revision.comment: /* Site contents */ Simpsons-L has been closed for 7 years.
revision.text:
[[Image:The Simpsons Archive logo.gif|thumb|220px|right|The Simpsons Archive logo.]] [[File:The Simpsons Archive (website screenshot).jpg|thumb|220px|right|The Simpsons Archive main page.]] '''The Simpsons Archive''', also known by its previous [[domain name]] snpp.com or simply SNPP (named for the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]]), is a [[The Simpsons|Simpsons]] [[Fansite|fan site]] that has been online since 1994. Maintained by dozens of volunteers from—amongst other places—the [[newsgroup]] [[alt.tv.simpsons]] and ''Simpsons''-related [[internet forum|forums]], the site features information on every aspect of the show, from detailed guides to upcoming episodes and [[Product (business)|merchandise]], to the episode capsules (text files documenting [[video frame|freeze frame]] jokes, quotes, scene summaries, reviews and the like), for which the site is well known. In a bid to steer clear of [[20th Century Fox|Fox]]'s legal department after a conflict in 1996, the site contains no multimedia or interactive features, preferring to focus on documenting the show through textual material.<ref>{{cite web | title=Confessions of a Surrogate Simpson | date=2007-07-24 |last=Menno | first=Christian | work=PlayPhilly.com | url=http://www.playphilly.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=18620922&BRD=2766&PAG=461&dept_id=578220&rfi=6 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070920140417/http://www.playphilly.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=18620922&BRD=2766&PAG=461&dept_id=578220&rfi=6 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2007-09-20 | accessdate=July 30, 2007}}</ref> As of October, 2005, the site receives roughly 1.2 million hits per month. In 2013, it was moved from snpp.com (which has now expired) to simpsonsarchive.com.
The Archive began in 1994, the brainchild of Gary Goldberg, with extensive help from the members of alt.tv.simpsons at the time, including Raymond Chen, the first to compile the episode capsules, and Dave Hall, one of the first online Simpsons fans to champion list-compiling. The site, originally based on the Widener archive set up by [[Brendan Kehoe]] in 1989, featured a bright yellow and black design until 1998, when it was revamped to the more subdued style.
==Site contents== ;[[FAQ]]s, Guides and Lists : FAQs, character files, merchandise information, broadcast history and, as the name would suggest, various lists (such as the cast list, couch gags, blackboard gags, song lyrics etc.) ;Upcoming Episodes : Guides to upcoming national schedules in the countries of (including, but not limited to) [[United States|USA]], [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Russia]], as well as details on episodes in production. ;[[:Category:Lists of television series episodes|Episode Guide]] : Brief episode synopsis for each episode, including guest stars and first character appearances. ;Episode Capsules : Probably the site's most well-known feature: comprehensive text files documenting quotes and scene summaries, freeze-frame jokes, reviews, animation errors and any other insight necessary. The capsules are mostly compiled from documentation posted to alt.tv.simpsons. The episode capsule is a convention that has since crossed over to many other TV show fansites and newsgroups, including co-[[Matt Groening]] animation ''[[Futurama]]''. Episodes featured are up to and including [[The Simpsons (season 13)|thirteenth season]]'s "[[The Bart Wants What It Wants]]". ;Miscellaneous : A collection of both internal and external copies of academic papers, articles, interviews and the like relating to the show, dating back as far as 1987. ;Simpsons-L : The site's own [[Mailing list|e-mail-based discussion group]], having over 1000 members. This list was [[Internet forum#Moderators|moderated]] to prevent [[Spam (electronic)|spam]]. The mailing list was shut down in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Simpsons Archive: The Springfield Times - News Archive|url=http://www.simpsonsarchive.com/news/100410.html#simpsons-l|website=www.simpsonsarchive.com|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> ;Web links : A comprehensive list of links to hundreds of other related sites, from fansites and character sites to the homepages of the [[Cast member|cast]] and [[official]] sites. ;The Springfield Times : A [[news]] page, home to articles on new Simpsons-related information, events and products, as well as to the two sub-sections of [[DVD]] News and [[Film|Movie]] News.
In addition to this, the site offers a search facility and an ''About the Archive'' page which allows you to contact any of the various maintainers and check which new pages and episode capsules have been added since your last visit.
==Publicity== The site has been featured in many publications, including the UK [[magazine]] ''[[Webuser|WebUser]]'', in which the site ranked #3 in their list of the "Top 100 TV Websites" back in 2002, and several unofficial ''Simpsons'' books including the analytical ''[[Planet Simpson]]'' by [[Chris Turner (author)|Chris Turner]] and the UK-issued episode guides ''[[The Pocket Essentials]]: The Simpsons'' by Peter Mann and ''I Can't Believe It's A Bigger, Better Updated Unofficial Simpsons Guide'' by Warren Martyn and Adrian Wood. In ''Planet Simpson'', Turner thanks the Simpsons Archive, saying that the book would have been impossible without it.
[[Matt Groening]], creator of the show, was once quoted in the [[Argentina|Argentinian]] [[newspaper]] ''[[La Nación]]'' as saying: "Sometimes we have to look at fan sites to remember [what we have done before]: one of the best is www.snpp.com. I have no idea what those initials mean, but it has a lot of stuff. Though for them, every episode is the worst ever."<ref>{{cite web|title=Groening Visits The Archive |date=2003-06-29 |work=The Simpsons Channel |url=http://www.simpsonschannel.com/cgi-bin/newspro/addons/iSay.cgi?Page=Comments&ID=EpVyAEFFVkYMgegBJE |accessdate=July 30, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928202728/http://www.simpsonschannel.com/cgi-bin/newspro/addons/iSay.cgi?Page=Comments&ID=EpVyAEFFVkYMgegBJE |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070426080046/http://personales.ciudad.com.ar/simpsonitos03/entrevistas2.htm Archive of article as posted on Simpsonidos]</ref> Reviews from the site's episode capsules have also been mentioned in the [[Audio commentary|DVD commentaries]] by various members of the show's staff.{{fact|date=September 2014}}
In 2007, it was ranked number five on ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'''s list of "25 essential fansites".<ref>{{cite web |title=25 Essential Fansites |year=2007 |author=Dan Snierson|publisher=''Entertainment Weekly'' |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20165619_20165621_20167049_21,00.html |accessdate=2008-02-24}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.simpsonsarchive.com/ The Simpsons Archive]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Simpsons Archive, The}} [[Category:The Simpsons]] [[Category:Online archives]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1994]] [[Category:American websites]]

revision.comment: Add: isbn. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Supper of the Lamb | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Supper of the Lamb.jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Robert Farrar Capon]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Food writing]] | publisher = | release_date = 1969 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = | oclc= }} '''''The Supper of the Lamb''''' is a [[Food writing|food book]] by [[Robert Farrar Capon]]. It was first published in 1969, and has been republished several times. It has been included in the [[Modern Library]] Food series.
Capon was an [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] priest, and [[Lauren Winner]] describes this book as "part cookbook, part theological meditation – something like [[M. F. K. Fisher]] meets the [[Desert Fathers|desert fathers]]."<ref>{{cite book|last=Winner|first=Lauren F.|author-link=Lauren Winner|title=Mudhouse Sabbath: An Invitation to a Life of Spiritual Discipline|year=2007|publisher=Paraclete Press|page=22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3SeUeMdUBfQC&pg=PA22|isbn=9781557255327}}</ref> [[Frederick Buechner]] described it as transcending category: "To call ''The Supper of the Lamb'' a cookbook would be like calling ''[[Moby Dick]]'' a whaling manual."<ref>{{cite news|last=Vitello|first=Paul|title=Robert F. Capon, Who Wrote of God and Food, Dies at 87|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/15/nyregion/robert-f-capon-who-wrote-of-god-and-food-dies-at-87.html?_r=1&|accessdate=16 September 2013|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=14 September 2013}}</ref>
The title is an allusion to the "marriage supper of the [[Lamb of God|Lamb]]" depicted in the [[Revelation 19|19th chapter]] of the [[Book of Revelation]], as well as a recipe for "Lamb for eight persons four times", which forms the basis for most of the book's discussions.
The book is not a [[cookbook]] in the strictest sense - it covers a wide variety of theological topics in between segments on cooking. A reader must read a good deal of the book in order to make the flagship recipe.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Supper of the Lamb}} [[Category:1969 books]] [[Category:Cookbooks]]

revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:Artifacts in the collection of the Smithsonian Institution]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{for|the sculpture of the same name by Alberto Giacometti|L'Homme qui marche I}} {{other uses2|walking man}} {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = ''The Walking Man'' (at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]]) | image1 = The Walking Man front.jpg | caption1 = Front | image2 = The Walking Man rear.jpg | caption2 = Rear }} '''''The Walking Man''''' ({{lang-fr|L'homme qui marche}}) is a bronze sculpture by the French sculptor [[Auguste Rodin]]. It was created by Rodin during 1877 and 1878. The best example of Rodin’s ‘sketchy’ impressionist sculpture also happens to be his most well-known ‘incomplete’ figure. This work personifies the latter part of Rodin’s career: the dynamic pose of a partial figure. Deriving much from Rodin’s earlier work [[Saint John the Baptist (Rodin)|''St. John the Baptist Preaching'']], including the powerful stance, Rodin had stripped all academic associations from his figure, and instead focused on what he considered essential: the dynamic pose. According to the bibliography supplied by the [[National Gallery of Art]], ''The Walking Man'' is a version of St. John without head and arms. This sculpture was previously considered a preliminary study for the complete Baptist and was based on the movement of that piece. According to Albert Elsen and [[Henry Moore]]'s suggestions, ''The Walking Man'' was created for the purpose of a Roman or Greek art without any live reference.{{Clarify|date=February 2013}} The art historian [[Leo Steinberg]] said of ''The Walking Man''’s pose:
The stance is profoundly unclassical, especially in the digging-in conveyed by the pigeon-toed stride and the rotation of the upper torso. Unlike the balanced, self-possessed classical posture with both feet turned out, Rodin uses the kind of step that brings all power to bear on the moment’s work
The statue has served as the inspiration for the works of other artists, such as [[Carl Sandburg]], who described it in his 1916 poem, "The Walking Man of Rodin":
THE WALKING MAN OF RODIN
Legs hold a torso away from the earth.
And a regular high poem of legs is here.
Powers of bone and cord raise a belly and lungs
Out of ooze and over the loam where eyes look and ears hear
And arms have a chance to hammer and shoot and run motors.
You make us
Proud of our legs, old man.

And you left off the head here,
The skull found always crumbling neighbor of the ankles.
==See also== * [[List of public art in Houston]] ==External links== * [http://www.musee-rodin.fr/en/collections/sculptures/walking-man Link to ''The Walking Man''] on the official website of the Musée Rodin. * [http://www.nortonsimon.org/collections/browse_title.php?id=M.1966.05.S ''The Walking Man''], Norton Simon Art Foundation Object Number M.1966.05.S: ''The Walking Man'', bronze cast No. 7, edition of 12. * [http://cantorcollection.stanford.edu/Obj24006?sid=2150&x=30022''The Walking Man''], [[Iris & B. Gerald Cantor Center for Visual Arts]] at [[Stanford University]], Object Number 1982.306 * [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24997 ''The Walking Man''] entry, including downloadable 3D stereolithography (.stl) file, based on photogrammetric survey of Norton Simon Art Foundation Object Number: M.1966.05.S: ''The Walking Man'', bronze cast No. 7, edition of 12, on Thingiverse.com * [http://www.thingiverse.com/thingiview:160333 ''The Walking Man''] 3D stereolithography (.stl) file viewer, based on photogrammetric survey of Norton Simon Art Foundation Object Number: M.1966.05.S: ''The Walking Man'', bronze cast No. 7, edition of 12, on Thingiverse.com. *[http://www.rodin-web.org/works/1878_baptist.htm] BIBLIOGRAPHY (supplied by The National Gallery of Art, Washington) *''[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/99556 Rodin: The B. Gerald Cantor Collection]'', a full text exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which contains material on ''The Walking Man'' {{Auguste Rodin}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Walking Man}} [[Category:Sculptures by Auguste Rodin]] [[Category:Sculptures of men]] [[Category:Nude sculptures]] [[Category:1878 sculptures]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Art Institute of Chicago]] [[Category:Franklin D. Murphy Sculpture Garden]] [[Category:Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] [[Category:Lillie and Hugh Roy Cullen Sculpture Garden]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in California]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Museum of Modern Art (New York)]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Musée Rodin]]

{{For|the church|Thomas Road Baptist Church}}
The '''Thomson Reuters Business Classification''' ('''TRBC''') is an [[industry classification]] of global companies; it is owned and operated by [[Thomson Reuters]] and is also the basis for [[Thomson Reuters Indices]].
==Coverage== TRBC covers over 70,000 public companies from 130 countries and provides over 10 years of classification history. The classification consists of five levels of hierarchical structure. Each company is allocated an Industry, which falls under an Industry group, then Business Sector, which is then part of an overall economic sector. TRBC consists of 10 economic sectors, 28 business sectors, 54 industry groups, 143 industries and 837 Activities.

Utilities | 59102010 Natural Gas Utilities |- | 591030 Water & Other Utilities | 59103010 Water & Other Utilities |- | 591040 Multiline Utilities | 59104010 Multiline Utilities |}
==A market-based classification== TRBC is a market-based classification schema, similar to the [[Global Industry Classification Standard|GICS]] and [[Industry Classification Benchmark|ICB]] systems. These classify companies on the basis of degree of impact on markets, rather than establishment-based classification systems such as the [[North American Industry Classification System]](NAICS).
==Use of TRBC== TRBC is used primarily in the Financial Investment and Advisory space, where investors identify and select groups of comparable companies and look at trends. More specifically, this could be Investment Managers allocating funds and benchmarking their portfolios; Investment Bankers highlighting acquisition targets and opportunities for financial restructuring, or more generally corporates performing competitive analysis of their peers in the marketplace.
==See also== * [[Global Industry Classification Standard]] * [[Industry Classification Benchmark]] * [[North American Industry Classification System]] * [[Statistical Classification of Economic Activities in the European Community]] (NACE) * [[Standard Industrial Classification]] * [[Industry information]]
==External links==
* [https://financial.thomsonreuters.com/en/products/data-analytics/market-data/indices/trbc-indices.html Thomson Reuters Business Classification] * [http://thomsonreuters.com/content/dam/openweb/documents/excel/tr-com-financial/trbc-industry-descriptions.xls Thomson Reuters Business Classification in Excel]
==References== * [http://thomsonreuters.com/products_services/financial/thomson_reuters_indices/trbc/], Thomson Reuters Business Classification

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox UK place |country = England |region = London |official_name = Tower Hill |coordinates = {{coord|51.5085|-0.0782|display=inline,title}} |post_town = LONDON |postcode_area = EC |postcode_district = EC3 |london_borough = Tower Hamlets |dial_code = 020 |os_grid_reference = TQ333806 |constituency_westminster = [[Poplar and Limehouse (UK Parliament constituency)|Poplar and Limehouse]] |static_image_name = London 12 2002 5070.JPG |static_image_caption = [[10 Trinity Square]], Tower Hill |charingX_distance_mi = 2 |charingX_direction = W }} [[File:Tower Hill as shown on the Agas map of 1561.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|Tower Hill as shown on the [[Woodcut map of London|"Woodcut" map]] of c. 1561]] [[File:London Wall fragment.jpg|thumb|250px|The surviving fragment of the 3rd-century [[London Wall]] near [[Tower Hill tube station]] on Tower Hill]] '''Tower Hill''' is a complex [[town square|city]] or [[garden square]] northwest of the [[Tower of London]], in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]] just outside the [[City of London]] boundary yet inside what remains of the [[London Wall]] — a large fragment of which survives toward its east.<ref name=hbwheatley>{{cite book |last=Wheatley |first=Henry Benjamin |authorlink=Henry B. Wheatley |year=1891 |last2=Cunningham |first2=Peter |authorlink2=Peter Cunningham (writer, born 1816) |chapter=Tower Hill |title=[[London Past and Present]] |location=London |publisher=John Murray |volume=vol. 3 |pages=400–402 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QKYPAAAAYAAJ&pg=400}}</ref>
It was an [[extra-parochial area]] with moniker Great Tower Hill.<ref name=hbwheatley/> For centuries it hosted public executions, particularly of [[attainder|attainted peers]] and today it is notable for being the site of the [[Tower Hill Memorial]] in its '''Trinity Square Gardens''' which are adjoined by its two smaller public gardens, Wakefield and Tower Gardens. The latter are lined by a web of pavements which cut short '''Trinity Square''', rendering it a curved park-lined street.
==Location== The set of gardens and buildings surrounding are served by [[Tower Gateway DLR station|Tower Gateway DLR]] and [[Tower Hill tube station]]s. The street Tower Hill forms an edge of the congestion charging zone between [[Byward Street]] in the west and a junction with [[Minories]] and Tower Hill Terrace in the east.
==History== [[File:Monmouth's Execution.gif|thumb|Depiction of the 1685 execution of [[James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth]] at Tower Hill in a popular print.]] [[File:London Tower Hill Scaffold Site.JPG|thumb|Site of the Scaffold on Tower Hill]]
===Settlement=== In one of the oldest parts of London, [[archeology|archaeological]] evidence shows that there was a settlement on the hill in the [[Bronze Age]] and much later a [[Roman Britain|Roman]] village that was burnt down during the [[Boudica]] uprising. A nearby church, [[All Hallows-by-the-Tower]], is known for fragments of [[Romanesque architecture]] dating back to <small>AD</small> 680; the church itself dates from 675.
===Local government=== Great Tower Hill was an [[extra-parochial area]] within the [[Liberties of the Tower of London|Tower Liberty]], under the direct administrative control of the Tower of London and outside the jurisdiction of the [[City of London]] and the county of [[Middlesex]]. In 1855 the area became part of the district of the [[Metropolitan Board of Works]].
The "District of Tower" became part of the [[Whitechapel District (Metropolis)|Whitechapel District]], under the authority of the Whitechapel District Board of Works. This was ambiguous and The Great Tower Hill Act 1869 was required to explicitly interpret it as [[Old Tower Without]], including within it Great Tower Hill.<ref>The Statutes of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, Great Britain, His Majesty's Statute and Law Printers, (1869)</ref> The Tower Liberty was abolished in 1894 and incorporated into the [[County of London]].
===Executions=== [[Capital punishment|Public executions]] of high-profile traitors and criminals were often carried out on Tower Hill, including: * 1381 – [[Simon Sudbury]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]]<ref name="sitesign2">[[:File:Tower Hill scaffold location - Sign 2.jpg|Sign at site of the scaffold (2)]]</ref> (beheaded by an angry mob) * 1381 – [[Robert Hales|Sir Robert Hales]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1388 – [[Simon de Burley|Sir Simon de Burley]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1388 – [[John de Beauchamp, 1st Baron Beauchamp (fourth creation)]] * 1397 – [[Richard FitzAlan, 11th Earl of Arundel|Richard Fitzalan]], 11th [[Earl of Arundel]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1440 – Rev. Richard Wyche, Vicar of [[Deptford]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1462 – [[John de Vere, 12th Earl of Oxford|John de Vere]], 12th [[Earl of Oxford]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1462 – Aubrey de Vere, eldest son and heir of [[John de Vere, 12th Earl of Oxford|John de Vere]], 12th [[Earl of Oxford]] * 1462 – [[Thomas Tuddenham|Sir Thomas Tuddenham]] * 1462 – William Tyrrell * 1462 – John Montgomery * 1470 – [[John Tiptoft, 1st Earl of Worcester|John Tiptoft]], 1st [[Earl of Worcester]]<ref name="sitesign2" /> * 1495 – [[William Stanley (Battle of Bosworth)|Sir William Stanley]]<ref name="sitesign3">[[:File:Tower Hill scaffold location - Sign 3.jpg|Sign at site of the scaffold (3)]]</ref> * 1497 – [[James Tuchet, 7th Baron Audley|James Tuchet]],<ref name="sitesign3" /> a commander of the [[Cornish Rebellion of 1497]] * 1499 – [[Edward Plantagenet, 17th Earl of Warwick|Edward Plantagenet]], 17th [[Earl of Warwick]]<ref name="sitesign3" /> * 1502 – [[James Tyrrell]] * 1510 – [[Edmund Dudley]] * 1510 – [[Richard Empson|Sir Richard Empson]] * 1521 – [[Edward Stafford, 3rd Duke of Buckingham|Edward Stafford]], 3rd [[Duke of Buckingham]]<ref name="sitesign3" /> * 1535 – [[John Fisher]], [[Diocese of Rochester|Bishop of Rochester]]<ref name="sitesign3" /> * 1535 – [[Thomas More|Sir Thomas More]],<ref name="sitesign3" /> ex-Lord Chancellor * 1536 – [[George Boleyn, Viscount Rochford|George Boleyn]], brother of [[Anne Boleyn]] * 1537 – [[Thomas Darcy, 1st Baron Darcy de Darcy]]<ref name="sitesign3" /> * 1538 – [[Henry Courtenay, 1st Marquess of Exeter|Henry Courtenay]], [[Earl of Devon]]<ref name="sitesign4">[[:File:Tower Hill scaffold location - Sign 4.jpg|Sign at site of the scaffold (4)]]</ref> * 1538 – [[Edward Neville]] * 1539 – [[Nicholas Carew (courtier)|Sir Nicholas Carew]] * 1540 – [[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]], [[Earl of Essex]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1540 – [[Walter Hungerford, 1st Baron Hungerford of Heytesbury]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/learn/histories/lgbtq-history/walter-hungerford-and-the-buggery-act/|title=Walter Hungerford and the ‘Buggery Act’ {{!}} English Heritage|website=www.english-heritage.org.uk|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> * 1547 – [[Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1549 – [[Thomas Seymour, 1st Baron Seymour of Sudeley]] * 1552 – [[Ralph Vane|Sir Ralph Vane]] * 1552 – [[Thomas Arundell of Wardour Castle|Sir Thomas Arundell of Wardour Castle]] * 1552 – [[Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset|Edward Seymour]], 1st [[Duke of Somerset]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1554 – [[Thomas Wyatt the younger|Sir Thomas Wyatt]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1554 – [[Lord Guildford Dudley]] * 1572 – [[Thomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk|Thomas Howard]], 4th [[Duke of Norfolk]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1601 – [[Christopher Blount|Sir Christopher Blount]] * 1615 – [[Gervase Helwys|Sir Gervase Helwys]] * 1631 – [[Mervyn Tuchet, 2nd Earl of Castlehaven|Mervyn Tuchet]], 2nd [[Earl of Castlehaven]] * 1641 – [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford|Thomas Wentworth]], 1st [[Earl of Strafford]]<ref name="sitesign4" /> * 1645 – [[William Laud]], Archbishop of Canterbury<ref name="sitesign5">[[:File:Tower Hill scaffold location - Sign 5.jpg|Sign at site of the scaffold (5)]]</ref> * 1651 – [[Christopher Love]], Presbyterian minister * 1662 – [[Henry Vane the Younger|Sir Henry Vane]]<ref name="sitesign5" /> * 1683 – [[Algernon Sidney|Col. Algernon Sidney]]<ref name="sitesign5" /> * 1685 – [[James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth]]<ref name="sitesign5" /> * 1716 – [[James Radclyffe, 3rd Earl of Derwentwater|James Radclyffe]], 3rd [[Earl of Derwentwater]]<ref name="sitesign5" /> * 1746 – [[William Boyd, 4th Earl of Kilmarnock|William Boyd]], 4th [[Earl of Kilmarnock]] * 1746 – Robert Boyd (of [[Clan Boyd]]) * 1746 – [[Arthur Elphinstone, 6th Lord Balmerino|Arthur Elphinstone]], 6th [[Lord Balmerino]] * 1747 – [[Simon Fraser, 11th Lord Lovat]]<ref name="sitesign5" />
